newsitem.title: UK: Quiet London gold hovers around key $350 level.
newsitem.headline: Quiet London gold hovers around key $350 level.

text.p: The price of gold hung around the psychologically important $350.00 an ounce level in thin, trading on Tuesday, while the white metals showed more volatility.
Bullion was fixed at $350.00 an ounce in the afternoon, virtually unchanged from $349.85 in the morning after trading in a tight range of around $1.70.
"Gold certainly does not seem to be doing much today and trading is quite thin," a dealer noted.
Dealers had said sharp losses on Wall Street on Thursday and Monday had helped to attract investors to gold, buoying prices.
The effect was not likely to last much longer, unless the stock market saw further significant losses this week, they said.
In contrast, silver, platinum and palladium have lost ground amid concerns about industrial demand in the aftermath of last week's hike in U.S. interest rates, dealers said.
Silver started the day weaker after a slide below the $5.08 support line in New York on Monday triggered sell stops and sent prices lower.
Further selling in early Europe, which dealers attributed to a New York investment fund, sent prices probing key support at $5.00 an ounce.
But it bounced off lows and was last at $5.03/$5.05, off nine cents from Thursday's close. Still, some dealers said silver had acquired a downside bias and was vulnerable to the downside.
"The $5.00 level has held for now, and $4.98 has been good technical support in the past. But longs have been getting out and we may be moving into a new, lower range," a dealer said.
Platinum also came under pressure, and ticked lower after sustaining painful losses on Monday in New York. It was last at $368.50/$369.50, down $3.20 from Thursday's London close.
But palladium came off its lows and was last indicated virutally unchanged at $146.25/$147.25.
The market was still waiting for fresh news on Russian supplies of platinum group metals to Japan, which have been on hold since the beginning of the year.
Industry officials have said they were waiting for a government decree to authorise shipments. --Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936
